bestBHT.bht: Whosoever remained faithful till the destruction of Jerusalem should be preserved, as no Christian perished in the siege or after it. This verse teaches the importance of endurance, whether it's until death, martyrdom, or the end of all things. Those who endure afflictions and persecutions faithfully, clinging to their faith until the end, will be saved and enter heaven. This principle of endurance applies to individuals and the Church, even in the face of false teaching and prevailing wickedness. The faithful few remain steadfast, enduring in love.

Henry Alford: The primary meaning of this seems to be, that whosoever remained faithful till the destruction of Jerusalem, should be preserved from it.
No Christian, that we know of, perished in the siege or after it.
It has ulterior meanings, according to which the end will signify to an individual, the day of his death...his martyrdom...to the Church, endurance in the faith to the end of all things.
Albert Barnes: He that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved.
He that bears afflictions and persecutions faithfully that constantly adheres to his religion, and does not shrink until death shall be saved, or shall enter heaven.
In your patience possess ye your souls.
Philip Schaff: The Christians were saved from the horrors attending the destruction of Jerusalem. But the principle is a general one.
For the individual, ‘the end’ is the day of his death ; for the Church, it is the Advent of Christ, the end of all things.
Over against the apostasy of ‘the many’ we have the faithfulness of the few, in spite of false teaching, in spite of prevailing wickedness, an endurance in love.
John Gill: But he that shall endure to the end... the same shall be saved.
In the profession of faith in Christ... in holiness of life and conversation.
With a temporal salvation... and also with an everlasting salvation.

bhtAttempts.bht: Those who remained faithful until the destruction of Jerusalem were preserved from it, as no known Christian perished in the siege or afterward. However, this verse has further meanings, including individual endurance until death or martyrdom, and the Church's endurance in the faith until the end of all things. It teaches that those who bear affliction and persecution faithfully, who remain steadfast in their religion until the end, will be saved or enter heaven. The principle of endurance applies to both the individual and the Church, with the end representing the day of one's death or the Advent of Christ. Despite false teaching and prevailing wickedness, the few remain faithful and endure in love.

Those who remained faithful until the destruction of Jerusalem were preserved, as no known Christian perished. This verse speaks of endurance, whether it be until death, martyrdom, or the end of all things. It teaches that those who bear affliction and persecution faithfully, remaining steadfast in their religion, will be saved. The principle of endurance applies to both individuals and the Church. Despite false teaching and prevailing wickedness, the faithful remain steadfast, enduring in love.

Despite false teaching and prevailing wickedness, the faithful remain steadfast, enduring in love.
